_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Rinchem Company, Inc, located at 23650 NW Huffman Street, Hillsboro OR 97124, is a warehouse storage facility for hazardous and non-hazardous chemicals.  In reviewing the requirements for preventing or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive chemicals, Rinchem determined its process of warehousing more than 10,000 pounds of flammable liquids at this facility falls under the Process Safety Management requirements of 29CFR 1910.119.  Annually, the list of chemicals warehoused in the facility will be reviewed to determine if any other chemicals fall under these requirements.
The maximum intended iventory of flammable liquids at the warehouse is 150,000 pounds.  The temperature in the flammable liquid storage roon is maintained at <80F with a target of <72F. There are also flammable liquids stored between -5F to 45F in temperature controlled storage. Information pertaining to the hazards of all chemicals in the process is the MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheets) kept on file in the warehouse office.
Rinchem uses electic forklifts and electric and manual pallet jacks (no propane equipment is in use.  Parrot beak attachments to the forklifts are also used as needed.


Contingency and Emergency Preparedness Plan

A.    INTRODUCTION 

    A.1    Purpose 

The purpose of the Contingency Plan is to minimize hazards to human life and the natural environment that may arise in an emergency situation at the Rinchem Facility. The provisions of the Contingency Plan are to be carried out by facility personnel immediately when an emergency occurs.  Emergencies may include, but are not limited to fire, explosion, or release of hazardous material causing air, soil, or surface water contamination. 

    A.2       Types of Potential Emergencies

Handling and warehousing hazardous materials obviously creates the potential for emergency situations.  Natural events such as tornadoes or flooding may also create emergency situations necessitating appropriate and effective management. In order to appropriately handle these hazardous situations, we have created the Contingency Plan.

A.2.1    Emergencies Inherent to Industrial Facility Operations

Potential emergencies that may result of any industrial facility operation include:    

(1)    Fire
(a)    Could cause the release of toxic fumes
(b)    Could spread and possibly ignite materials at other locations onsite, or cause heat-induced
(c)    Could produce contaminated runoff from controlling fire with water or chemical suppressants.

(2)    Explosion
(a)    Could cause a safety hazard from flying fragments

or shock waves
(b)    Could ignite other hazardous chemicals stored at the facility
(c)    Could result in a release of toxic material.

(3)    Hazardous Chemical Spill
(a)    Could release toxic fumes  
(b)    Could ignite its self and/or other onsite chemicals
(c)    Could contaminate the environment.

A.2.2    Natural Events 

Certain natural events could cause emergencies at the Rinchem facility, necessitating implementation of the Contingency Plan. For example, release of hazardous chemicals due to flooding could cause the contamination of surface and groundwater.  A tornado could cause ignition of flammable chemicals or contamination of the environment.  These situations could also cause commingling of incompatible chemicals.  

B.    IMPLEMENTATION ASSESSMENT AND DECISION PROCESS

B.1    Assessment and Decision Process

In case of an imminent or actual emergency situation, the individual observing the incident will use the appropriate notification equipment (or make contact in-person) to notify RinchemA?s Emergency Coordinator, or his alternate, of the location, nature, and extent of the incident. The Emergency Coordinator will set up a command post and take control of the affected area.  He will commit any necessary resources until the emergency has been terminated, and until any warranted clean up or restoration is complete.

The Emergency Coordinator will direct the following activities:

(1)    Where applicable see that operations are stopped and that any released chemicals are contained and collected
(2)    Determine the source, extent of the spilled materials, and assess the primary and secondary hazards. The Emergency Coordinator will determine if the Contingency Plan, in its entirety or in part, should be implemented
(3)    See that any materials spilled in the incident area are isolated from incompatible materials / chemicals and ignition sources.

B.2    Implementation of the Contingency Plan    

When a decision has been made to implement the Contingency Plan, the Emergency Coordinator wil

l direct the following procedures: 

(1)    Initiation of containment and control procedures as described in the Detailed Emergency Procedures Section E-2
(2)    An accounting of all facility personnel/visitors by head
(3)    Implementation of facility notification
(4)    Notification of authorities, including requests for assistance, as necessary. I.e. if a reportable quantity of any chemical is spilled the fire department must be notified by dialing 911. 
(5)    Coordination of first aid activities if casualties are involved and activation of the casualty control procedures found in Section G First Aid
(6)    Evacuation if required and activation of the Evacuation Plan described in Section F-1 & F-2
(7)    Taking of pictures and documenting what is happening in the photographs for later evaluation of the emergency.

C.    EMERGENCY COORDINATOR

The Emergency Coordinator or his alternate will always be A?on-callA? and can be reached via telephone.  The Emergency Coordinator or his alternate arranges their schedules such that one of them can be reached any day of the year, 24 hours per day.   In the event both of them will be out of reach on the same day, a surrogate is designated for the period absence.  Table-1 shows Emergency Coordinator and his alternates.  The alternates are shown in order of priority.

C.1    Emergency Coordinator Qualifications

The Emergency Coordinator at the Rinchem facility has the authority to take any necessary emergency actions.  He has a good knowledge of the Contingency Plan.  He knows about the safety equipment and communication devices that are found in the facility.  He has a good knowledge of all the chemicals that are stored at the Rinchem facility and the hazards that accompany each chemical. The Emergency Coordinator has the qualification necessary to be in charge in the event of an emergency.

E.    DETAILED EMERGENCY PROCEDURES

The potential incidents that are of highest priority for emergency planning at this facility are:

(1)    Fire and / or explosion
(2)    Spills or material releases

The Emergency Coordinator as outlined in the Contingency Plan will appropriately handle other disasters such as tornadoes, earthquakes or floods. 

E.1    Fire and / or Explosion

The most probable cause for evacuation of the premises of this facility is fire and / or explosion. It is important that all employees never forget that firefighting requires professional action. The facility will follow this procedure:
(1)    Once a fire breaks out, supervisory personnel must be alerted and given the following information 
(a)    Name of person reporting.
(b)    Location of fire.
(c)    Necessity of fire truck, ambulance, police or o

ther emergency or other emergency equipment. These will be called immediately.
(2)    If in the judgment of the Emergency Coordinator, the situation calls for the implementation of the facility Evacuation Plan, he will notify immediately the occupants of the facility by sounding the alarm and/or by voice communication.
(3)    Upon notification of evacuation, all personal with no emergency responsibilities will leave the premises by nearest safe exit. Vehicle and forklift operators will clear their equipment from aisles and exits, if possible, and will make sure all engines and motors are turned off.    
(4)    The Emergency Coordinator will determine the best method of approach, containment, and control:
(a)    Move in from upwind side
(b)    Activate fire suppression system if appropriate  
(5)    The Emergency Coordinator must make an assessment as to the number of different potential problems or situations that might present themselves in an emergency, and how to deal with them. Consideration must be given to items such as: 
(a)    Release of fumes and possible necessity for neighborhood evacuation
(b)    Potential materials which when exposed to fire could explode and result in flying debris which could spread fire to off-site areas or previously unaffected areas of the facility
(c)    Explosions which could result in the release of materials from containers
(d)    Residues from fire fighting activities that may need to be contained and dealt with in an appropriate manner. 
(6)    All individuals are responsible to familiarize themselves with the content of this plan plus the primary and secondary exits within their work areas, as well as the location of fire extinguishers and first aid kits.  Personnel operating electrical equipment at the time the evacuation notice is given will be responsible to turn that machine off and if possible, unplug it.   

E.2    Chemical Spills    

Chemical Spills: refer to General Operational SOP:
Chemical Spill Clean Up A? Doc 4300

E.3    Accident in Transit

Rinchem is

a transporter of hazardous chemicals .An accident in transit involving hazardous chemicals is an emergency that Rinchem must be prepared for. The following items should be followed in the event of an accident in transit:

(1)    In most cases, the State Police or Highway Patrol will be the first to arrive on the scene of an accident and the driver will give them the emergency telephone numbers of those people or agencies whom he wishes to contact.
(2)    The driver should stay as close as possible to his/her vehicle without threat of being harmed.  
(3)    The driver must take whatever action he feels necessary in order to protect human health and the    environment as safety permits.  
(4)    Keep unnecessary people away; isolate hazard area and deny entry
(a)    If the vehicle is placarded combustible or flammable, the driver must not allow anyone to use road flares or smoke.
(5)    Stay upwind; keep out of low areas.
(6)    In case of fire due to equipment failure i.e. tire, break or engine fire:
(a)    Withdraw immediately! 
(7)    In case of chemical fire.(Chemical fire fighting requires professional action)
(a)    Stay away and up wind
(b)    Contact the appropriate authorities, i.e. Fire department, Rinchem, etc. 
(c)    Assist the Fire department in any way possible. 
(8)    In case of spill: 
(a)    Chemical Spills: refer to General Operational SOPs
Chemical Spill Clean Up A? Doc 4300
(9)    In case of victim, use casualty procedures found in Section G.     
(10)    If deemed necessary, Chemtrec should be notified.
(11)    When the clean up is finished, the necessary reporting must be done within the allotted time period.  


E.4    Storm or Flood

In the event of a severe storm (e.g. tornado), all personnel should take shelter in an interior hallway or room, away from windows.   No one should remain in the yard or exposed area of the warehouse.  In the case of floods, or, more likely, high water due to rain, the major precaution is to shut off the main power panel.  Inventory must be looked at and repositioned as

necessary to protect it i.e. transfer temperature sensitive material into reefer trailers, move material off the floor into racking, etc. In any kind or severe weather situations, rely on a batter- powered radio for weather advisories.

F.    EVACUATION PLAN

F.1    Facility Evacuation Plan:               (See Document 7916 A? Emergency Evacuation Plan CSC 16) 


F.2    Facility Floor Plan    
         

F.3    Facility Evacuation Route    
     
A?    The first person to exit will determine wind direction from wind sock located at the top or the Rinchem facility on the Northwest corner. 
A?    He/she then will direct all employees to either head east or west.
A?    If wind is blowing west, all will head East and meet in the parking lot @ Long-Bottom caf??.
A?    If wind is blowing east, all will head West and meet in the parking lot @ Weyerhaeuser.

G.    FIRST-AID

During the course of the emergency, injured individuals will be provided first aid, as appropriate.  For more serious injuries, out side medical assistance will be sought.  During an emergency situation, the Emergency Coordinator will accomplish the following:

(1)    Designate, organize and direct available first-aid personnel.
(2)    Access information regarding injury-causing agents, including toxicity and decontamination requirements.  If needed.  Chemtrec and the National Poison Control Center may be called for emergency information.
(3)    Assess the situation and summon emergency medical agencies for assistance.  
(4)    The Emergency Coordinator will meet incoming emergency / medical personnel and guide them to the first-aid station or location of emergency.
(a)    Injured personal will be placed in the care of qualified medical personal.  
(b)    The Emergency Coordinator will provide first aid resources to the medical service person in charge.  
(5)    Assist the medical service in charge by providing notification to the appropriate hospital or emergency room of the arrival of the injured, the nature of the injury, information on toxicity and decontamination

, and any other pertinent information.  Such information shall be transmitted promptly to those with a A?need to-know.A?  

H.    OUTSIDE NOTIFICATION

H1.    Emergency reporting
(1)    The Emergency Coordinator must notify RinchemA?s Information Officer.  In the event the Rinchem Information Officer is not accessible, a Rinchem Director shall be contacted for guidance and with the support of one or additional Directors may act instead of the Information Officer.  The following information is to be collected for reporting purposes in the event a written report will be submitted to state and / or local authorities when necessary.  
(a)    Name and telephone number of reporter
(b)    Name, address and telephone number of the owner or operator
(c)    Name, address and telephone number of facility
(d)    Date, time and type of incident (e. g., release, fire)
(e)    Name and quantity of material(s) involved, to extent known
(f)    The extent of injuries, if any
(g)    An assessment of actual or potential hazards to human health or the environment
(h)    The estimated quantity and disposition of recovered material that resulted from the incident.

I.     AMENDMENTS TO THE CONTINGENCY PLAN

The Emergency Coordinator upon discussion with management will be responsible for changing the Contingency A? Emergency Preparedness Plan.  This plan shall be subject to review and amendment if any of the following occurs:

1.    The plan fails in an emergency
2.    The facilities operating permit is revised
3.    The facility changes in design, construction, operation, or maintenance
4.    Changes in the facility or surrounding area increase the potential for emergency situation
5.    Changes are made during a response that are necessary to deal with any unexpected          emergency
6.    The list of Emergency Coordinator changes. 

When the Contingency A? Emergency Preparedness Plan is amended for any reason, each major change is reviewed with appropriate agencies and / or emergency response authorities.  Modified Contingency A? Emergen

cy Preparedness Plan copies will be distributed to local, State, and Federal agencies when necessary.  The facility personnel responsible to implement the new plan will also receive a copy. 
 
J.     EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS PLAN

The Emergency Preparedness Plan is to be filled out by each Rinchem facility.  The plan is designed to keep operation running in the event of a disaster.
